holidays.name: National Peanut Butter Cookie Day
holidays.description: A day dedicated to celebrating the chewy, sweet, and salty joy of peanut butter cookies! Perfect excuse to bake (or buy) a batch and enjoy this timeless treat.
holidays.origin: While the exact origin is unclear, peanut butter cookies have been beloved in American baking since the early 20th century, with this day emerging as a fun food holiday in recent years to honor this delicious cookie variety.
holidays.funFact: The classic crisscross fork pattern on peanut butter cookies was popularized to flatten the dough evenly, but it’s now a signature look cherished by cookie lovers.

holidays.name: Loving Day
holidays.description: A powerful holiday commemorating the 1967 U.S. Supreme Court decision in Loving v. Virginia, which struck down laws banning interracial marriage, promoting love and equality.
holidays.origin: Named after the Loving couple, Mildred and Richard Loving, whose legal fight led to this landmark civil rights decision.
holidays.funFact: Despite the ruling, some couples still face challenges; Loving Day encourages ongoing dialogue about race, marriage, and acceptance.

holidays.name: Russian Language Day
holidays.description: Celebrates the rich cultural and linguistic heritage of the Russian language worldwide, promoting language learning and appreciation.
holidays.origin: Established by UNESCO in 2010, June 12 coincides with the birthday of Alexander Pushkin, a renowned Russian poet often considered the father of modern Russian literature.
holidays.funFact: Pushkin’s works helped standardize the Russian literary language, making his birthday a fitting day to honor Russian language lovers everywhere.

holidays.name: Anne Frank Day
holidays.description: A day to remember Anne Frank, the young diarist who documented her life in hiding during WWII, inspiring millions with her hope and courage.
holidays.origin: Observed especially in the Netherlands, it marks June 12, Anne Frank’s birthday, and is a time of reflection on tolerance and human rights.
holidays.funFact: Anne Frank’s diary has been translated into over 70 languages and remains one of the most widely read personal accounts of the Holocaust.
